title: Romance/relationship scams (emotion → money)
summary: Romance scammers build trust and feelings, then ask for money, gifts, or personal information — often with dramatic stories.
how_it_works: Scammer contacts you on dating apps/social media and gets close fast.
They avoid meeting/video calls and keep excuses ready.
Soon they ask for money, gifts, or financial ‘help’.
warning_signs: They won’t meet in person or video call.
They ask for money, gift cards, or crypto.
They get angry or guilt-trip you if you question them.
example_hooks: “I need help with an emergency—please send funds.”
“I can’t video call because of my job/security.”
what_to_do: Don’t send money or personal info to someone you’ve only met online.
Talk to a trusted person if you feel pressured.
Report profiles to the platform and Scamwatch.

quick_quiz.q: What’s the safest way to get to the real website?
choices: Click the link in the message
Type the website address yourself or use the official app
Reply and ask them for another link
quick_quiz.explain: Scam messages often include links to fake sites. Typing the address yourself (or using the official app) reduces that risk.

quick_quiz.q: A message says you must act 'within 24 hours' or you'll lose access. What should you do first?
choices: Stop and verify using official contact details you find yourself
Forward it to friends to ask
quick_quiz.explain: Urgency is a classic pressure tactic. Verify using trusted contact details.
